questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She reports dull aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand for the last few weeks. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. Her hand feels numb upon waking up in the morning. She has a sister who has multiple sclerosis. Her current medications include iron supplements and a multivitamin. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the wrist is passively held in full flexion, aggravation of paresthesia is perceived immediately. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

C) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune-mediated demyelinating neuropathies such as Guillain-Barre syndrome can manifest with pain and paresthesias affecting the distal extremities. However, these sensory abnormalities are generally symmetric and associated with concurrent ascending flaccid muscle paralysis that begins in the lower limbs. The presence of an asymmetric sensory disorder that is localized to the hand and the absence of motor deficits suggest a different diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.
Image Description:

The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

F) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

G) INCORRECT:

Demyelinating diseases of the CNS such as multiple sclerosis (MS) may manifest with a variety of neurologic symptoms, including arm paresthesias. While this patient is at increased risk for MS (woman of childbearing age with a positive family history), the association of her symptoms with sleep, its presence during pregnancy, and exacerbation with wrist flexion are inconsistent with MS. MS should be suspected if there are recurrent neurologic symptoms in different parts of the body (e.g., wrist paresthesia that resolves, followed by diplopia months later). MS exacerbations tend to cause symptoms that are persistent for days to weeks, until the flare resolves. Finally, MS symptoms tend to improve during pregnancy (possibly due to immunosuppression).
questions.hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain, tingling, and numbness in his right hand that started 3 months ago. The symptoms are worse at night and frequently wake him up. The symptoms can be relieved by shaking his hands but soon recur. He reports weakness of his right hand, especially when grasping objects. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications are metformin and sitagliptin. Four months ago he went on a camping trip. He has been working as a landscape gardener for 8 years. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows reproduction of his symptoms when his right hand is held above his head for 2 minutes. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7600/mm3



Hemoglobin A1C

6.3%


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
13 mm/h


Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ELISA for Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies is a serologic test for diagnosing Lyme disease. Although Lyme disease may manifest with peripheral neuropathy, this patient has not experienced the typical erythema migrans and there is no history of a tick bite. Although these factors are not always positive in Lyme disease, neurologic manifestations associated with the condition would not be exacerbated by certain movements. Lastly, Lyme disease is typically associated with an elevated ESR and sometimes elevated leukocytes, but this patient's values are normal.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the cervical spine would be indicated for suspected cervical radiculopathy (e.g., caused by a herniated disc or a tumor). Cervical radiculopathy can manifest with pain, tingling, and numbness of the hands as well, but it usually also causes neck and shoulder pain, which this patient lacks. Additionally, exacerbation during the night or during activities involving the hands (e.g., grasping objects) is not consistent with cervical radiculopathy, which is rather exacerbated by neck extension.

C) CORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies confirm suspected carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). This patient's history of hand paresthesia and pain exacerbated at night (due to reduced circulation and muscle movements during REM sleep) and while grasping objects is typical for CTS. Additionally, his occupation as a landscape gardener is a risk factor since CTS is associated with manual work leading to repetitive and forceful flexion and extension of the wrist. Provocative tests used in the diagnosis of CTS include Phalen, Tinel, and, as seen here, hand elevation tests.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) could be indicated for suspected several CNS disorders, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Although MS may manifest with peripheral paresthesia, it is usually associated with several other manifestations such as vision loss or ataxia. Additionally, as the defect is located in the central nervous system (not the periphery), symptoms would not worsen when the patient raises his hand.

E) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound is an important procedure for evaluating peripheral artery disease (PAD). This condition may manifest with claudication, weakness, and numbness of the affected extremity, which are symptoms that this patient has. The patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus, which may predispose him to PAD. However, the condition most commonly affects the legs and very rarely the hands. Furthermore, this patient's history (i.e., manual worker with symptoms that exacerbate during the night and while grabbing objects) is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: Risk factors for this patient's condition include diabetes mellitus with peripheral polyneuropathy, pregnancy, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent pain and numbness in her right hand for 6 weeks. She has a pins-and-needles sensation that worsens at night and is relieved when she shakes her hand. She has a history of hypertension controlled with lisinopril. She takes over-the-counter medications for constipation. Her mother has a history of rheumatoid arthritis. She looks fatigued. Her BMI is 35 kg/m2. Her pulse is 57/min and blood pressure is 120/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, there is a normal range of motion in the wrists and digits. Sensation in the right thumb and index finger is decreased to light touch. There is no thenar muscle atrophy. Deep tendon reflexes are 1+ throughout and there is mild nonpitting edema in the legs. This patient is most likely to benefit from which of the following treatments?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient presents with classic signs of hypothyroidism: constipation, fatigue, bradycardia, hyporeflexia, and nonpitting lower limb edema. Although the precise pathophysiology is unknown, it is assumed that excess deposition of glycosaminoglycans, hyaluronic acid, and mucopolysaccharides in hypothyroidism causes myxedema. These characteristic deposits can cause compression of the carpal tunnel. Treatment with a thyroid hormone replacement (i.e., levothyroxine) should cause a return to a euthyroid state and improvement of symptoms within several weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is an antimetabolite primarily used as a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) for rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The precise pathophysiology of CTS due to RA is uncertain, but it is thought to be due to increased carpal tunnel pressure caused by inflammation and edema. Although patients with RA typically report joint pain (like the knee pain in this patient), the metacarpophalangeal, and proximal interphalangeal joints are more commonly involved. Furthermore, patients with RA typically report morning stiffness.
Image Description:

Symmetrical swelling of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs are not generally recommended for the management of CTS. This patient is most likely to benefit from treatment of their underlying condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical treatment is usually indicated for patients who have features of severe CTS (e.g., weakness in the median nerve distribution, thenar atrophy) or who do not respond to conservative treatment. This patient shows no signs of severe CTS and is most likely to benefit from initial treatment of her underlying condition.
Image Description:

Intraoperative palmar view of the wrist

The incision is held open by a self-retaining retractor (distal; top of image) and a hook-shaped retractor (proximal; bottom of image). The transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum of the hand) has been surgically divided to decompress the median nerve. The thenar part of the split transverse carpal ligament (blue overlay) and the median nerve (green overlay) are visible in the wound.
Next to the median nerve, the median artery (red overlay) can be seen (this usually regresses before birth but may persist). Sources differ widely regarding the frequency of a persisting palmar median artery (1.5% to 50%), and it has been suggested that its presence may be associated with an increased risk of carpal tunnel syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Steroid therapy (e.g., prednisone therapy) can be effective in patients who only experience mild to moderate symptoms of CTS. However, steroid therapy has not been studied in cases in which CTS developed secondary to an underlying condition. The underlying cause should be treated first. Furthermore, steroids are usually administered as an injection, while oral steroids are a second-line treatment for those who decline injection therapy.
questions.hint: This patient's elevated BMI, constipation, nonpitting edema, and carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) are characteristic of a specific disorder.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the obstetrician for a prenatal visit. She has had a tingling pain in the thumb, index finger, and middle finger of her right hand for the past 6 weeks. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick touch on the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger of the right hand. The pain is reproduced when the dorsal side of each hand is pressed against each other. Without treatment of her current condition, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nodules in the palmar fascia suggest Dupuytren contracture. This condition often results in thickened, cord-like palmar fascial bands, which lead to flexion contractures of the MCPs and PIPs. Patients may also have manifestations of fibroproliferative disease elsewhere in the body, such as in the plantar fascia. This patient has pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, suggesting carpal tunnel syndrome, which is not associated with Dupuytren contracture.

B) CORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is the most common upper extremity neuropathy and is especially prevalent in pregnant women due to hormone-associated weight gain and peripheral edema compressing the median nerve. The thenar muscles (opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, and flexor pollicis brevis) are innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve; compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel can therefore cause thenar atrophy. Branches of the median nerve also provide sensory innervation to the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral (radial) half of the ring finger, which is why CTS causes pain and paresthesias in this distribution.

Other conditions associated with CTS include hypothyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis, and acromegaly.
Image Description:

Atrophy of the left and right thenars (abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis muscles) secondary to bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome

C) INCORRECT:

The interosseous muscles are intrinsic muscles of the hand that perform finger abduction (dorsal interosseous muscles) and adduction (palmar interosseous muscles). Because they are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, interosseous wasting can occur if the ulnar nerve is compressed or entrapped. The most common site of ulnar nerve entrapment is the cubital tunnel in the elbow, followed by the ulnar tunnel (Guyon's canal) in the hand.

D) INCORRECT:

Wrist drop occurs as a result of injury to the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), a branch of the radial nerve. Radial nerve injury can occur following mid-shaft humerus fracture, as the radial nerve runs in the spiral groove along the posterior humerus, as well as fracture or dislocation of the radius, which can cause direct injury to the PIN. Other common causes of radial nerve injury include the use of axillary crutches and saturday night palsy.

E) INCORRECT:

The hypothenar muscles include the opponens digiti minimi, the abductor digiti minimi, and the flexor digiti minimi, which are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. Hypothenar weakness can occur in ulnar nerve entrapment, which occurs most frequently at the cubital tunnel in the elbow, followed by the ulnar tunnel (Guyon's canal) in the hand.
questions.hint: A positive Phalen test (pain or tingling with passive flexion of wrists) suggests median nerve impingement in the carpal tunnel.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe pain in her right wrist one day after falling onto her hands and knees while rollerskating. Physical examination shows abrasions over the knees and bruising over the volar aspect of the right wrist. There is swelling and tenderness on palpation of the volar wrist joint, as well as restricted range of motion due to pain. An x-ray of the hand shows volar dislocation of the lunate bone. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Paresthesia over the volar aspect of the first 3 fingers on wrist flexion
Anesthesia over the dorsal aspect of the first 3 fingers
Tenderness to palpation of the anatomic snuffbox
Involuntary flexion of the 4th and 5th interphalangeal joints when extending all fingers
Pale skin color on the volar surface when pressure is applied to the radial artery

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paresthesia over the volar aspect of D1, D2, and D3 on wrist flexion (e.g., positive Phalen test) is consistent with median nerve injury, which can occur due to carpal tunnel compression from lunate dislocation. Lunate dislocations are most commonly the result of falling onto a hyperextended and ulnar-deviated wrist and typically manifest with acute wrist pain and swelling and tenderness to palpation of the volar wrist. Other complications related to lunate dislocation include avascular necrosis.
Image Description:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).

It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).

B) INCORRECT:

Anesthesia limited to the dorsal aspects of D1, D2, and D3 is consistent with a radial nerve neuropathy at the level of the wrist, which can be caused by external compression (e.g., due to a tight watch, handcuffs) and manifests with wrist tenderness. Because the radial nerve lies over the extensor retinaculum at the level of the wrist, it would not be affected by a lunate dislocation. Given this patient's mechanism of injury and x-ray demonstrating a lunate dislocation, anesthesia of the dorsal aspect of D1, D2, and D3 would be unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Tenderness to palpation of the anatomic snuffbox is seen in scaphoid fractures, which most commonly occur due to falling onto a hyperextended and radially-deviated wrist. Although scaphoid fractures manifest with acute wrist pain and swelling as well as tenderness with volar palpation of the wrist, an x-ray indicating lunate dislocation in the absence of a scaphoid fracture makes anatomic snuffbox tenderness unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Involuntary flexion of D4 and D5 interphalangeal joints with finger extension is consistent with ulnar nerve injury due to compression of Guyon's canal. Acute ulnar tunnel syndrome may occur from lunate dislocation but has only rarely been reported. A different complication of lunate dislocation is much more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

On a modified Allen test, performed by applying pressure to the radial artery, pale skin on the hand's volar surface would suggest an ulnar artery injury such as from a laceration or an occlusive pathology such as hypothenar hammer syndrome (HHS). Acute HHS is the result of blunt trauma to the hypothenar eminence. Although a patient with HHS may present with acute wrist pain, swelling, and tenderness to palpation of the volar wrist, this patient's x-ray shows a lunate dislocation, making a different finding more likely.
questions.hint: Volar lunate dislocation can cause compression of structures within the carpal tunnel.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of left hand pain and intermittent tingling over the radial aspect of the left hand. He says that the pain significantly worsens at night. Massaging the palm of his hand relieves the pain. He has well-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. He has no other personal or family history of serious illness. He does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 100 kg (220 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Range of motion is normal in the left wrist and left digits. There is numbness in the palmar surface of the left thumb and the left index finger. Full flexion of the left wrist and percussion of the palmar surface of the wrist reproduce the symptoms. Muscle strength is 5/5 in the left upper extremity. In addition to immobilization of the left wrist, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression is indicated in patients with CTS and persistent symptoms despite nonsurgical management, or if the patient presents with features of severe CTS, which include thenar muscle atrophy and weakness as well as pain that frequently interrupts sleep. This patient, however, has mild to moderate CTS, for which surgical decompression is not the most appropriate next step in management.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with mild to moderate CTS, nonoperative measures are appropriate for the initial management of symptoms. Local corticosteroid therapy (e.g., triamcinolone) and/or immobilization of the wrist with a padded, volar splint worn during the night are both first-line therapies. If symptoms persist or worsen despite nonoperative measures, surgical decompression of the median nerve should be considered.

Diabetes mellitus and obesity, which are seen here, are risk factors for CTS.

C) INCORRECT:

Although some studies have shown that physical therapy results in symptom relief for patients with CTS, there is insufficient evidence to recommend it as a treatment modality for CTS. Other treatment strategies supported by stronger evidence are more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B6 supplementation is indicated in cases of vitamin B6 deficiency, which can cause peripheral neuropathy (PNP). PNP can manifest with pain, tingling, and numbness of the hands. However, PNP typically occurs bilaterally and is usually not limited to the area innervated by the median nerve. Furthermore, this patient has no risk factors for vitamin B6 deficiency, such as malabsorption or isoniazid therapy.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral analgesia (e.g., NSAIDs, gabapentin) is not effective in managing CTS. Other treatment strategies supported by stronger evidence are more appropriate.
questions.hint: Pain that aggravates at night, paresthesia, and numbness over the radial side of the hand, in conjunction with a positive Phalen test and Tinel sign, are suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the obstetrician for a prenatal visit. She has had tingling pain in the thumb and first two digits of her right hand for the past 6 weeks. The pain worsens at night. Physical examination reveals:


T2–T4 neutral, sidebent left, rotated right
Tender point at the medial epicondyle of the right forearm
Decreased sensation on the palmar aspect of the right thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger
Strength intact in the upper extremities bilaterally
Pain in the right hand when the dorsal sides of the hands are pressed together

Without treatment for her current condition, this patient is most likely to develop
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The interosseous muscles are intrinsic muscles of the hand that perform finger abduction (dorsal interosseous muscles) and adduction (palmar interosseous muscles). Because they are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve, interosseous wasting can occur if the ulnar nerve is compressed or entrapped. The most common site of ulnar nerve entrapment is the cubital tunnel in the elbow, followed by the ulnar tunnel (Guyon's canal) in the hand.

B) INCORRECT:

The hypothenar muscles include the opponens digiti minimi, the abductor digiti minimi, and the flexor digiti minimi, which are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. Hypothenar weakness can occur in ulnar nerve entrapment, which occurs most frequently at the cubital tunnel in the elbow, followed by the ulnar tunnel (Guyon's canal) in the hand.

C) INCORRECT:

Wrist drop occurs as a result of injury to the posterior interosseous nerve (PIN), a branch of the radial nerve. Radial nerve injury can occur following mid-shaft humerus fracture, as the radial nerve runs in the spiral groove along the posterior humerus, as well as fracture or dislocation of the radius, which can cause direct injury to the PIN. Other common causes of radial nerve injury include the use of axillary crutches and saturday night palsy.

D) INCORRECT:

Nodules in the palmar fascia suggest Dupuytren contracture. This condition often results in thickened, cord-like palmar fascial bands, which lead to flexion contractures of the MCPs and PIPs. Patients may also have manifestations of fibroproliferative disease elsewhere in the body, such as in the plantar fascia. This patient has pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, suggesting carpal tunnel syndrome, which is not associated with Dupuytren contracture.

E) CORRECT:

Carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS) is the most common upper extremity neuropathy and is especially prevalent in pregnant individuals due to hormone-associated weight gain and peripheral edema, which can compress the median nerve. CTS manifests with pain and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerve, i.e., the palmar aspect of the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral (radial) half of the ring finger. Atrophy of the thenar muscles (i.e., opponens pollicis, abductor pollicis brevis, and flexor pollicis brevis) occurs if CTS is left untreated because these muscles are innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. In addition to immobilization of the wrist, analgesia, and steroid injections, CTS can be treated osteopathically by decreasing sympathetic tone to the affected extremity (e.g., by treating T2–T7 and rib somatic dysfunctions), removing restrictions affecting brachial plexus function (e.g., cervical somatic dysfunctions, thoracic inlet restriction), and applying direct techniques to the carpal tunnel (e.g., myofascial release of the flexor retinaculum).
Image Description:

Atrophy of the left and right thenars (abductor pollicis brevis and opponens pollicis muscles) secondary to bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome
questions.hint: A positive Phalen test (pain or tingling with passive flexion of the wrists) suggests median nerve impingement in the carpal tunnel.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man reports a 4-month history of pain and swelling in the hands and wrists, hand stiffness that lasts up to 2 hours each morning, swelling and stiffness in the elbows and knees, and fatigue. He also describes being awakened at night by numbness and paresthesias in both hands, primarily in the thumbs and in the second and third digits. He has no rash, no previous history of pain or swelling in any joints, and no significant alcohol intake. He works as an automobile mechanic and notes that his grip has become weak. He has taken occasional doses of over-the-counter naproxen without much benefit. His current vital signs are unremarkable.
Which one of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Swelling and tenderness of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Thickening of the palmar fascia with flexion contractures of the digits
Swelling and tenderness of the distal interphalangeal joints
Isolated tenderness and swelling of tendons overlying the radial side of the wrists without any articular abnormalities.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by joint swelling, joint tenderness, and joint destruction. RA typically causes synovitis at the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints but may also involve larger joints. RA rarely affects the distal interphalangeal joints, which helps to distinguish it from osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and gout.

This patient’s numbness and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerves is consistent with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, which is often seen in RA patients who have wrist synovitis and tenosynovitis of the flexor tendons. A patient presenting with carpal tunnel syndrome alone (i.e., in the absence of RA) would be more likely to have unilateral hand involvement and would not likely report hand swelling, morning stiffness, and fatigue. Carpal tunnel syndrome is not typically associated with other causes of inflammatory arthritis, such as psoriasis or gout.

Key learning point: A patient with new-onset rheumatoid arthritis is most likely to present with synovitis at the wrists, proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and flexor tendons.

B) INCORRECT:

Dupuytren contracture (thickening of the palmar fascia resulting in flexion contractures and therefore stiffness of the fingers) does not have an established association with rheumatoid arthritis and would not explain most of this patient’s symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis rarely affects the distal interphalangeal joints, which helps to distinguish it from osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and gout.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of nail pitting, even without obvious rash, can be helpful in diagnosing psoriatic arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Localized tenderness of the tendons overlying the radial styloid is indicative of de Quervain tendinopathy. This disorder generally manifests unilaterally; swelling, if present, occurs over the radial side of the wrist and not in the hands. Involved tendons are the abductor pollicus longus and extensor pollicus brevis in extensor compartment 1.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with obesity reports a 2-week history of pain in his left wrist. He is awakened during the night by numbness and tingling radiating to his first through third fingers. The symptoms are exacerbated by his work in construction. He feels as if he has become clumsy and has difficulty holding objects for long periods.
There is no gross swelling or thenar atrophy. He has full, pain-free range of motion of his elbow, shoulder, and neck. His upper-extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally. He has tenderness on his wrist but not his forearm.
A radiograph is obtained (figure).
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wrist arthritis manifests with degenerative changes that are evident on radiograph; it is not typically associated with neurologic findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome is due to compression of the brachial plexus and causes paresthesias, atrophy, and weakness of the hand; pain is always present. Affected patients may also experience associated neck or pectoral pain. It is most common in people who engage in repetitive overhead activities.

C) INCORRECT:

Cubital tunnel syndrome results from compression of the ulnar nerve, which causes wrist pain and paresthesias along the fourth and fifth digits.

D) INCORRECT:

Pronator syndrome and CTS manifest similarly because both involve entrapment of the median nerve. Pronator syndrome is much less common and is characterized by forearm pain with repetitive movements, especially with the elbow extended, and by sensory loss in the thenar eminence.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s radiograph is normal, and his symptoms are characteristic of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), the most common nerve-entrapment syndrome. CTS causes compression of the median nerve and affects about 3% of the U.S. population. Risk factors include obesity, female sex, and workplace activity involving repetitive wrist and hand movements, such as working with vibrating tools, prolonged wrist flexion and extension, or sustained wrist pressure.

The most typical early symptoms of CTS are pain and numbness with repetitive wrist motion. A common symptom is awakening at night because of numbness and tingling that are relieved by shaking out the affected hand. Patients typically describe numbness along the palmar aspect of the first through fourth digits. As symptoms progress, they may experience wrist and thumb weakness with thenar atrophy and diminished sensation along the distribution of the median nerve. This patient has motor symptoms, which indicates that he has fairly severe CTS.

A Phalen test (to identify pain and numbness with both wrists held in flexion against each other) and a Tinel test are commonly used in practice to evaluate for CTS. Each test has sensitivity greater than 50% and specificity around 75%.

Key learning point: The nerve that is most likely to be compressed in a patient who has wrist pain that worsens with repetitive activity is the median nerve.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old woman reports an 8-month history of progressive bilateral hand pain at the volar aspect of the wrist, radiating mostly to the palmar aspect of the first through fourth fingers. There is associated numbness and tingling to the fingers. The symptoms are worse at night and improve with shaking of the hands.
There is no obvious atrophy or swelling. The symptoms are reproduced by pressing on the proximal edge of the carpal ligament and with sustained flexion testing of the wrist.
During a discussion of possible next steps, the patient notes that she prefers conservative management and is not interested in any treatments or tests involving needles.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, diuretics, and vitamin B6 have been studied as interventions for patients with carpal tunnel syndrome but have been shown not to be efficacious.

B) CORRECT:

The symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome are related to compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel and occur most frequently in middle-aged women. Although carpal tunnel syndrome is most commonly associated with overuse of the flexor tendons of the wrist (e.g., when typing), it can also occur as a result of inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis or from endocrinopathies such as hypothyroidism or acromegaly. In these patients, symptoms are often bilateral. Regardless of etiology, patients with carpal tunnel syndrome may report pain, numbness, tingling, swelling, and weakness or clumsiness in the median nerve distribution.

A classic pattern of symptoms in at least two of the first three fingers has a sensitivity of 64% and a specificity of 73% for identifying carpal tunnel syndrome. The addition of the flick sign (i.e., relief of symptoms with flicking or shaking of the hands when the pain awakens the patient at night) to that classic pattern increases the sensitivity to 93% and the specificity to 96%.

The wrist flexion test (Phalen) has a sensitivity of 57% to 91% and a specificity of 33% to 86%. A Tinel sign has a sensitivity of 23% to 60% and a specificity of 64% to 87%. A carpal compression test (Durkan) has a sensitivity of 75.5% and a specificity of 98.5%.

Nonsurgical treatment is suggested for mild-to-moderate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome. Splinting and glucocorticoid injections have the most evidence and are most commonly used. Neutral splinting, or immobilization of the wrist in a neutral position, is typically recommended nightly for 6 weeks. However, studies show better improvement if the splint is worn full time or if the nightly splint is worn for 3 months to one year. Glucocorticoid treatment is usually done with local injection into the carpal tunnel, which this patient prefers to avoid, and typically relieves symptoms for only a short time. Another approach to short-term glucocorticoid treatment is with an oral course.

Key learning point: An appropriate treatment plan for carpal tunnel syndrome involves nocturnal wrist splinting.

C) INCORRECT:

There is limited evidence of the effectiveness of ergonomic keyboards. Keyboard positioning may be considered for a person with prolonged keyboard use, as there has been a suggestion of pain relief after 12 weeks of use, but this approach is unlikely to improve symptoms in patients with only typical keyboard use.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, diuretics, and vitamin B6 have been studied as interventions for patients with carpal tunnel syndrome but have been shown not to be efficacious.

E) INCORRECT:

There is limited evidence of the effectiveness of exercise therapy.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the office for a burning sensation and numbness in her right hand for 4 weeks. The burning sensation is worse at night and is sometimes relieved by shaking the wrist. In the past week, she has noticed an exacerbation of her symptoms. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus that is well-controlled on insulin. Examination shows tingling and numbness over the right thumb, index finger, and middle finger when the wrist is actively flexed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression is used to treat patients with persistent symptoms of CTS despite nonsurgical management or in patients who have severe symptoms, such as thenar muscle atrophy and/or weakness. In surgical decompression, the transverse carpal ligament is released to increase room for the median nerve in the carpal tunnel. This patient has mild to moderate CTS, for which surgical decompression is not the most appropriate next step in management.
Image Description:

Intraoperative palmar view of the wrist

The incision is held open by a self-retaining retractor (distal; top of image) and a hook-shaped retractor (proximal; bottom of image). The transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum of the hand) has been surgically divided to decompress the median nerve. The thenar part of the split transverse carpal ligament (blue overlay) and the median nerve (green overlay) are visible in the wound.
Next to the median nerve, the median artery (red overlay) can be seen (this usually regresses before birth but may persist). Sources differ widely regarding the frequency of a persisting palmar median artery (1.5% to 50%), and it has been suggested that its presence may be associated with an increased risk of carpal tunnel syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Physiotherapy is not a well-studied treatment modality for CTS and is, therefore, not the most appropriate next step in management. Other strategies with stronger evidence are more appropriate.

C) INCORRECT:

Sulfasalazine can be used as a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. However, this patient does not have signs of active rheumatoid arthritis, such as fatigue, swollen joints, and joint pain that is worse in the morning. Sulfasalazine is not an appropriate therapy for CTS.

D) CORRECT:

Wrist splinting is the most appropriate next step in management for patients with mild to moderate CTS. The splint is placed on the volar (palmar) side of the hand to fixate and support the wrist and is typically worn at night when symptoms are most severe. By keeping the wrist in a neutral position, the space in the carpal tunnel can be kept open to reduce compression of the median nerve. Local glucocorticoid injections (e.g., triamcinolone) are another treatment option that can be used in individuals with mild to moderate CTS.
Image Description:

The Phalen sign is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The patient may carry out the test on their own by actively holding the wrist in full flexion (1) for the Phalen maneuver, or in maximal extension (2) for the reverse Phalen maneuver. If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

E) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B6 supplementation is used to treat vitamin B6 deficiency, which can cause peripheral neuropathy with bilateral numbness, tingling, and burning of the distal extremities. While this patient has numbness and tingling, it is localized exclusively to areas innervated by the right median nerve. Additionally, she has no risk factors for vitamin B6 deficiency (e.g., malabsorption, isoniazid therapy).
questions.hint: Numbness and burning pain over the radial side of the hand with exacerbation at night in combination with a positive Phalen test indicate carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with obesity reports a 2-week history of pain in his left wrist. He is awakened during the night by numbness and tingling radiating to his first through third fingers. The symptoms are exacerbated by his work in construction, and he has difficulty holding objects for long periods. He has full, pain-free range of motion of his elbow, shoulder, and neck. There is no gross swelling, and upper extremity muscle strength is intact. He has tenderness on his wrist but not his forearm. Radiographs of the hand are unremarkable. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wrist arthritis manifests with degenerative changes that are evident on radiograph; it is not typically associated with neurologic findings.

B) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome is due to compression of the brachial plexus and causes paresthesias, atrophy, and weakness of the hand; pain is always present. Affected patients may also experience associated neck or pectoral pain. It is most common in people who engage in repetitive overhead activities.

C) INCORRECT:

Cubital tunnel syndrome results from compression of the ulnar nerve, which causes wrist pain and paresthesias along the fourth and fifth digits.

D) INCORRECT:

Pronator syndrome manifests similarly to this patient's condition because both involve entrapment of the median nerve. Pronator syndrome is much less common and is characterized by forearm pain with repetitive movements, especially with the elbow extended, and by sensory loss in the thenar eminence.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s radiograph is normal, and his symptoms are characteristic of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS), the most common nerve-entrapment syndrome. CTS causes compression of the median nerve and affects about 3% of the U.S. population. Risk factors include obesity, female sex, and workplace activity involving repetitive wrist and hand movements, such as working with vibrating tools, prolonged wrist flexion and extension, or sustained wrist pressure.

The most typical early symptoms of CTS are pain and numbness with repetitive wrist motion. A common symptom is awakening at night because of numbness and tingling that are relieved by shaking out the affected hand. Patients typically describe numbness along the palmar aspect of the first through fourth digits. As symptoms progress, they may experience wrist and thumb weakness with thenar atrophy and diminished sensation along the distribution of the median nerve. This patient has motor symptoms, which indicates that he has fairly severe CTS.

A Phalen test (to identify pain and numbness with both wrists held in flexion against each other) and a Tinel test are commonly used in practice to evaluate for CTS. Each test has sensitivity greater than 50% and specificity around 75%.

Key learning point: The nerve that is most likely to be compressed in a patient who has wrist pain that worsens with repetitive activity is the median nerve.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man comes to the office because of pain, tingling, and numbness in his right hand that started 3 months ago and worsen at night. He reports weakness of his right hand, especially when grasping objects. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and his medications are metformin and sitagliptin. He has been working as a landscape gardener for 8 years. Examination reveals positive Tinel's sign. Leukocyte count, glycated hemoglobin level, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate are within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ELISA for Borrelia burgdorferi antibodies is a serologic test for diagnosing Lyme disease. Although Lyme disease may manifest with peripheral neuropathy, this patient has not experienced the typical erythema migrans and there is no history of a tick bite. Although these factors are not always positive in Lyme disease, neurologic manifestations associated with the condition would not be exacerbated by certain movements. Lastly, Lyme disease is typically associated with an elevated ESR and sometimes elevated leukocytes, but this patient's values are normal.

B) INCORRECT:

A CT scan of the cervical spine would be indicated for suspected cervical radiculopathy (e.g., caused by a herniated disc or a tumor). Cervical radiculopathy can manifest with pain, tingling, and numbness of the hands as well, but it usually also causes neck and shoulder pain, which this patient lacks. Additionally, exacerbation during the night or during activities involving the hands (e.g., grasping objects) is not consistent with cervical radiculopathy, which is rather exacerbated by neck extension.

C) CORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies confirm suspected carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). This patient's history of hand paresthesia and pain exacerbated at night (due to reduced circulation and muscle movements during REM sleep) and while grasping objects is typical for CTS. Additionally, his occupation as a landscape gardener is a risk factor since CTS is associated with manual work leading to repetitive and forceful flexion and extension of the wrist. Provocative tests used in the diagnosis of CTS include Phalen and Tinel tests.
Image Description:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).

It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).

D) INCORRECT:

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) could be indicated for suspected several CNS disorders, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Although MS may manifest with peripheral paresthesia, it is usually associated with several other manifestations such as vision loss or ataxia. Additionally, as the defect is located in the central nervous system (not the periphery), symptoms would not worsen with Tinel test.

E) INCORRECT:

Doppler ultrasound is an important procedure for evaluating peripheral artery disease (PAD). This condition may manifest with claudication, weakness, and numbness of the affected extremity, which are symptoms that this patient has. The patient also has a history of diabetes mellitus, which may predispose him to PAD. However, the condition most commonly affects the legs and very rarely the hands. Furthermore, this patient's history (i.e., manual worker with symptoms that exacerbate during the night and while grabbing objects) is more suggestive of a different diagnosis.
questions.hint: Risk factors for this patient's condition include diabetes mellitus with peripheral polyneuropathy, pregnancy, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman reports a 4-month history of pain and swelling in the hands and wrists, hand stiffness that lasts up to 2 hours each morning, swelling and stiffness in the elbows and knees, and fatigue. She also describes being awakened at night by numbness and paresthesias in both hands, primarily in the thumbs and in the second and third digits. She has no rash, no previous history of pain or swelling in any joints, and no significant alcohol intake. She notes that her grip has become weak. She has taken occasional doses of over-the-counter naproxen without much benefit. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which one of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Swelling and tenderness of the proximal interphalangeal joints
Thickening of the palmar fascia with flexion contractures of the digits
Swelling and tenderness of the distal interphalangeal joints
Isolated tenderness and swelling of tendons overlying the radial side of the wrists without any articular abnormalities.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is consistent with RA, a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by joint swelling, joint tenderness, and joint destruction. RA typically causes synovitis at the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, proximal interphalangeal joints, and metatarsophalangeal joints but may also involve larger joints. RA rarely affects the distal interphalangeal joints, which helps to distinguish it from osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and gout.

A patient presenting with carpal tunnel syndrome alone (i.e., in the absence of RA) would be more likely to have unilateral hand involvement and would not likely report hand swelling, morning stiffness, and fatigue. Carpal tunnel syndrome is not typically associated with other causes of inflammatory arthritis, such as psoriasis or gout.

Key learning point: A patient with new-onset rheumatoid arthritis is most likely to present with synovitis at the wrists, proximal interphalangeal joints, metacarpophalangeal joints, and flexor tendons.

B) INCORRECT:

Dupuytren contracture (thickening of the palmar fascia resulting in flexion contractures and therefore stiffness of the fingers) does not have an established association with rheumatoid arthritis and would not explain most of this patient’s symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis rarely affects the distal interphalangeal joints, which helps to distinguish it from osteoarthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and gout.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of nail pitting, even without obvious rash, can be helpful in diagnosing psoriatic arthritis. Nail pitting does not have an established association with rheumatoid arthritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Localized tenderness of the tendons overlying the radial styloid is indicative of de Quervain tendinopathy. This disorder generally manifests unilaterally; swelling, if present, occurs over the radial side of the wrist and not in the hands. Involved tendons are the abductor pollicus longus and extensor pollicus brevis in extensor compartment 1.
questions.hint: This patient’s numbness and paresthesias in the distribution of the median nerves is consistent with bilateral carpal tunnel syndrome, which is often seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She reports dull aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand for the last few weeks. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. Her hand feels numb upon waking up in the morning. Vital signs are within normal limits. When the wrist is passively held in full flexion, aggravation of paresthesia is perceived immediately. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

B) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).

C) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

D) CORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by median nerve compression at the wrist, leading to nocturnal pain and paresthesia in the lateral hand, often worsened by wrist flexion.
Image Description:

The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

E) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.
questions.hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.

questions.hint: Pain that aggravates at night, paresthesia, and numbness of the fingers, in conjunction with a positive Phalen test and Tinel sign, are suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

questions.text:
A 49-year-old landscaper presents with six months of intermittent numbness and tingling in his right thumb, index, and middle fingers, often interrupting his sleep. He also reports progressive weakness in thumb opposition. Physical examination shows thenar eminence atrophy but intact cutaneous sensation over the thenar eminence. Tinel’s sign at the wrist is positive.
Which of the following best explains why sensation over the thenar eminence is preserved despite significant thenar muscle atrophy?

choices.text: Palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve branches proximal to the carpal tunnel
Ulnar nerve supplies cutaneous innervation to the thenar eminence
Sensory innervation continues through the dorsal cutaneous branch of the radial nerve
Motor branch to the thenar muscles is unaffected by compression under the flexor retinaculum

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The median nerve gives off the palmar cutaneous branch before entering the carpal tunnel. This branch provides sensory innervation to the thenar eminence. In carpal tunnel syndrome, compression occurs beneath the flexor retinaculum, affecting motor fibers to the thenar muscles, leading to atrophy. However, the palmar cutaneous branch is unaffected by this compression, preserving sensation over the thenar eminence despite motor deficits.

Key learning point: Atrophy of the thenar eminence with intact sensation over it suggests median nerve damage distal to the palmar cutaneous branch, such as in carpal tunnel syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

The ulnar nerve primarily innervates the medial hand, including the little finger and ulnar half of the ring finger. Sensation over the thenar eminence is provided by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve, which branches before the carpal tunnel and is unaffected by compression there.

C) INCORRECT:

The dorsal cutaneous branch of the radial nerve innervates the dorsal hand, not the palmar skin over the thenar eminence. Sensation in the thenar area is maintained by the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve, which is unaffected by carpal tunnel compression.

D) INCORRECT:

The thenar muscle atrophy indicates that the motor fibers are affected by compression. The preserved sensation over the thenar eminence is due to the palmar cutaneous branch of the median nerve, which branches off before the carpal tunnel, not because the motor branch is unaffected.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of progressively worsening numbness and tingling in her right thumb, index, and middle fingers. She frequently drops objects and has difficulty with tasks requiring thumb opposition. She is an office manager with no significant medical history. Examination reveals marked thenar eminence flattening and a positive Tinel sign at the wrist. Strength testing shows weak thumb abduction and opposition but intact finger extension.
Which of the following muscles is most likely spared in this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The abductor pollicis brevis is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. In carpal tunnel syndrome, median nerve compression leads to weakness in this muscle, contributing to the observed thenar eminence flattening and impaired thumb abduction.

B) INCORRECT:

The flexor pollicis brevis has two heads: the superficial head is innervated by the median nerve, and the deep head by the ulnar nerve. In carpal tunnel syndrome, the median nerve compression affects the superficial head, leading to weakness in thumb flexion.

C) INCORRECT:

The opponens pollicis is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. Median nerve compression in carpal tunnel syndrome results in weakness of this muscle, causing difficulty with thumb opposition, as seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

The adductor pollicis is innervated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve. In carpal tunnel syndrome, the median nerve is compressed, affecting the thenar muscles innervated by it, such as the abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis. The adductor pollicis remains unaffected because it does not receive innervation from the median nerve.

Key learning point: Carpal tunnel syndrome affects the median nerve, leading to paralysis of the thenar muscles, which are responsible for thumb movements.
Image Description:

Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve by the transverse carpal ligament (flexor retinaculum).

It typically manifests with sensory disturbances (pain, tingling, and numbness) in the area innervated by the median nerve distal to the carpal tunnel. Symptoms are typically worse at night. Severe compression of the median nerve can also cause motor symptoms (e.g., thenar muscle weakness and atrophy).
