Patients typically describe numbness along the palmar aspect of the first through fourth digits. As symptoms progress, they may experience wrist and thumb weakness with thenar atrophy and diminished sensation along the distribution of the median nerve. This patient has motor symptoms, which indicates that he has fairly severe CTS.

A Phalen test (to identify pain and numbness with both wrists held in flexion against each other) and a Tinel test are commonly used in practice to evaluate for CTS. Each test has sensitivity greater than 50% and specificity around 75%.

Key learning point: The nerve that is most likely to be compressed in a patient who has wrist pain that worsens with repetitive activity is the median nerve.

B) INCORRECT:

Cubital tunnel syndrome results from compression of the ulnar nerve, which causes wrist pain and paresthesias along the fourth and fifth digits.

C) INCORRECT:

Wrist arthritis manifests with degenerative changes that are evident on radiograph; it is not typically associated with neurologic findings.

D) INCORRECT:

Pronator syndrome manifests similarly to this patient's condition because both involve entrapment of the median nerve. Pronator syndrome is much less common and is characterized by forearm pain with repetitive movements, especially with the elbow extended, and by sensory loss in the thenar eminence.

E) INCORRECT:

Thoracic outlet syndrome is due to compression of the brachial plexus and causes paresthesias, atrophy, and weakness of the hand; pain is always present. Affected patients may also experience associated neck or pectoral pain. It is most common in people who engage in repetitive overhead activities.

questions.text: You are seeing a 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 24 weeks' gestation who comes to your clinic for a prenatal visit. She reports several weeks of dull, aching pain and paresthesia over her left hand. The pain radiates to her shoulder and is worse at night. She also notes numbness in her hand upon waking in the morning. Vital signs are normal. When her wrist is passively held in full flexion, her paresthesia is immediately aggravated. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?

choices.text: Lower trunk palsy of the brachial plexus.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (Klumpke palsy) causes deficits along the C8 and T1 myotomes and dermatomes. Although Klumpke palsy may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand and would also be present on the ulnar aspect of the forearm. Hand and finger weakness is also typically prominent. In addition, this patient lacks a history that would suggest Klumpke paralysis (e.g., upward traction on the arm, thoracic outlet syndrome, Pancoast tumor).

B) CORRECT:

Compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel (carpal tunnel syndrome, CTS) results in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the areas innervated by the median nerve (i.e., palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, and radial half of the ring finger). Pregnancy is an important risk factor for carpal tunnel syndrome because of physiological fluid retention, which leads to edema of soft tissue in and around the carpal tunnel. The sensory disturbances in CTS are classically worse at night and pain on flexion of the wrist (a positive Phalen test) may be present. Occasionally, the pain may radiate to the shoulder, as seen in this patient. Most cases of carpal tunnel syndrome with an onset during pregnancy can be managed by splinting of the wrist. Surgery and corticosteroid injections are usually not required because symptoms usually resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Carpal tunnel syndrome is caused by median nerve compression at the wrist, leading to nocturnal pain and paresthesia in the lateral hand, and is commonly associated with pregnancy due to fluid retention.
Image Description:

The Phalen maneuver is considered specific for the diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The examiner holds the patient's wrist in flexion (1) or extension (2). If paresthesia in the fingers innervated by the median nerve (marked in white) occurs or is aggravated within one minute, this finding is highly specific for CTS.

C) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve compression usually results from trauma or prolonged pressure on the mid-arm (e.g., Saturday night palsy). Radial nerve palsy typically manifests with sensory changes over the posterior forearm/hand and weakness on wrist extension (i.e., wrist drop). This patient has no significant risk factors for radial nerve compression (e.g., trauma or intoxication) and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with radial nerve compression.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiculopathy of C6, C7, and/or C8 nerve roots may manifest with pain and paresthesia in the hand and shoulder. However, radiculopathy is typically accompanied by restriction of neck, arm, or hand movements. Also, nocturnal paresthesia is usually not present. Exacerbation of paresthesia by passive flexion of the wrist (Phalen sign) suggests a specific mononeuropathy and not radiculopathy.

E) INCORRECT:

Compression of the ulnar nerve in the ulnar groove between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon (cubital tunnel syndrome) may result in pain, paresthesia, and numbness in the hand as seen in this patient. However, these sensory disturbances are usually localized to the medial half of the hand, and/or the ring and little finger and exacerbation of symptoms with wrist flexion would not be consistent with ulnar nerve compression. Also, this patient has no history that would suggest a cubital tunnel syndrome (e.g., osteoarthritis or trauma to the elbow).
questions.hint: Beside pregnancy, hypothyroidism and rheumatoid arthritis are also risk factors for this patient's condition.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman comes to your clinic with an 8-month history of progressive bilateral hand pain at the volar aspect of the wrist, radiating mainly to the palmar aspect of the first through fourth fingers. She also reports numbness and tingling in these fingers. Her symptoms are worse at night and improve when she shakes her hands. The symptoms are reproduced by pressing on the proximal edge of the carpal ligament and with sustained wrist flexion. During your discussion about management options, she states that she prefers conservative treatment and does not want any interventions or tests involving needles. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, diuretics, and vitamin B6 have been studied as interventions for patients with carpal tunnel syndrome but have been shown not to be efficacious.

B) CORRECT:

The symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome are related to compression of the median nerve in the carpal tunnel and occur most frequently in middle-aged women. Although carpal tunnel syndrome is most commonly associated with overuse of the flexor tendons of the wrist (e.g., when typing), it can also occur as a result of inflammatory diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis or from endocrinopathies such as hypothyroidism or acromegaly. In these patients, symptoms are often bilateral. Regardless of etiology, patients with carpal tunnel syndrome may report pain, numbness, tingling, swelling, and weakness or clumsiness in the median nerve distribution.

Nonsurgical treatment is suggested for mild-to-moderate symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome. Splinting and glucocorticoid injections have the most evidence and are most commonly used. Neutral splinting, or immobilization of the wrist in a neutral position, is typically recommended nightly for 6 weeks. However, studies show better improvement if the splint is worn full time or if the nightly splint is worn for 3 months to one year. Glucocorticoid treatment is usually done with local injection into the carpal tunnel, which this patient prefers to avoid, and typically relieves symptoms for only a short time. Another approach to short-term glucocorticoid treatment is with an oral course.

Key learning point: An appropriate treatment plan for carpal tunnel syndrome involves nocturnal wrist splinting.

C) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drugs, diuretics, and vitamin B6 have been studied as interventions for patients with carpal tunnel syndrome but have been shown not to be efficacious.

D) INCORRECT:

There is limited evidence of the effectiveness of ergonomic keyboards. Keyboard positioning may be considered for a person with prolonged keyboard use, as there has been a suggestion of pain relief after 12 weeks of use, but this approach is unlikely to improve symptoms in patients with only typical keyboard use.

E) INCORRECT:

There is limited evidence of the effectiveness of exercise therapy.
questions.hint: Pain that aggravates at night, paresthesia, and numbness of the fingers, in conjunction with a positive Phalen test and Tinel sign, are suggestive of carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

questions.text: A 52-year-old administrative assistant presents with a 4-month history of bilateral hand numbness and tingling that disrupts his sleep. Physical examination shows decreased sensation over the palmar surface of the thumb, index, and middle fingers bilaterally, with normal sensation over the thenar eminence and no motor deficits. Phalen test is positive at 45 seconds bilaterally. Over-the-counter ibuprofen for 2 weeks has made no improvement. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Referal for outpatient hand surgery consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical consultation is indicated for severe disease (e.g., weak finger pinch and grip strength, thenar atrophy) or symptoms refractory to conservative treatment after 6 weeks. This patient has not yet tried appropriate conservative management.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Wrist splinting in neutral position is an appropriate first-line conservative treatment for mild to moderate carpal tunnel syndrome. This patient has classic symptoms with positive provocation testing and no signs of severe disease (e.g., thenar atrophy or weak finger pinch and grip strength). Trial immobilization or glucocorticoid injection should be tried before other interventions.

C) INCORRECT:

Nerve conduction studies are indicated for diagnostic uncertainty, atypical presentations, or presurgical evaluation. This patient has classic clinical features with positive provocation tests, making the diagnosis clear without the need for electrophysiological confirmation.

D) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy has limited evidence for effectiveness in carpal tunnel syndrome. Nerve glide exercises may be helpful as adjunctive therapy, but splinting or glucocorticoid injection should be tried first.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are less effective than corticosteroid injections and should only be used short-term. They are typically reserved for cases in which splinting has been unsuccessful or as an alternative to injection therapy.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of intermittent tingling and numbness in her right hand, which awakens her from sleep. She reports clumsiness and has started dropping objects. She works as a data entry clerk. On physical examination, holding the wrist in full flexion reproduces paresthesia, and she has mild thenar atrophy. Which of the following describes the most likely distribution of this patient's sensory deficits?

choices.text: Palmar surface of the thumb, index, middle, and radial half of the ring finger
Palmar and dorsal surfaces of the small finger and ulnar half of the ring finger
Lateral aspect of the forearm extending into the thumb and index finger
Medial aspect of the forearm extending into the ring and small fingers
Dorsal surface of the hand over the first web space between the thumb and index finger

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for carpal tunnel syndrome. The median nerve provides sensory innervation to the palmar aspect of the first three and a half digits. Nocturnal paresthesias are a hallmark symptom, caused by fluid shifts and wrist flexion during sleep. Thenar atrophy is a sign of advanced or chronic compression, indicating motor fiber involvement, which is consistent with the patient's reported clumsiness.

B) INCORRECT:

The palmar and dorsal surfaces of the small finger and ulnar half of the ring finger are the sensory distribution of the ulnar nerve. While ulnar nerve entrapment can cause numbness and tingling, the location of symptoms is incorrect for this patient. Furthermore, specific physical exam findings for carpal tunnel syndrome, such as a positive Phalen test and thenar atrophy, are inconsistent with an ulnar nerve pathology.

C) INCORRECT:

A sensory deficit of the lateral aspect of the forearm extending into the thumb and index finger is characteristic of a C6 cervical radiculopathy. While a C6 radiculopathy can cause numbness in the thumb and index finger, this patient's symptoms are localized to the hand and are associated with provocative tests specific to the wrist, making a peripheral nerve entrapment more likely than a cervical spine issue.

D) INCORRECT:

A sensory deficit of the medial aspect of the forearm extending into the ring and small fingers is characteristic of a C8 cervical radiculopathy. This is inconsistent with the patient's symptoms, which involve the thumb, index finger, and middle finger. Additionally, the physical exam findings of a positive Phalen test and thenar atrophy are specific to pathology at the wrist, not the cervical spine.

E) INCORRECT:

The dorsal surface of the hand over the first web space between the thumb and index finger is the sensory distribution of the superficial branch of the radial nerve. An isolated injury to this nerve, often from trauma or compression at the wrist, would not explain the patient's palmar symptoms, nocturnal awakening, positive Phalen test, or thenar muscle atrophy.
questions.hint: The patient's occupational risk factors, nocturnal paresthesias, positive Phalen test, and thenar atrophy are classic findings for compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a 4-month history of numbness and tingling in her right hand. The symptoms primarily affect her thumb, index, and middle fingers and frequently awaken her from sleep, prompting her to shake her hand for relief. Her medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes, managed with metformin. On examination, Phalen's and Tinel's signs are positive over the right wrist. There is slight flattening of the thenar eminence. Nerve conduction studies confirm moderate median neuropathy at the wrist. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?

choices.text: Initiation of a course of oral gabapentin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical decompression (carpal tunnel release) is the definitive treatment for carpal tunnel syndrome. It is typically reserved for patients with severe disease, such as those with significant motor weakness or profound sensory loss, or for those who have failed multiple conservative treatments. While this patient has moderate disease with early atrophy, a less invasive option is usually attempted before proceeding to surgery.

B) CORRECT:

For patients with moderate carpal tunnel syndrome, a local corticosteroid injection into the carpal tunnel or a trial of immobilization is the appropriate first-line treatment, with the choice guided by patient preference. The injection reduces inflammation and swelling of the flexor tendon sheaths, which decreases pressure on the median nerve and provides significant symptom relief. While relief may be temporary, it is a more potent intervention than splinting alone and is less invasive than surgery, making it the ideal choice for this patient's presentation. Common risk factors for carpal tunnel syndrome include diabetes mellitus, obesity, pregnancy, and rheumatoid arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin is used to treat neuropathic pain and could potentially alleviate this patient's sensory symptoms. However, it does not address the underlying pathophysiology of carpal tunnel syndrome, which is the compression of the median nerve within the carpal tunnel.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like naproxen may provide some short-term pain relief, but they have shown limited efficacy in treating the underlying nerve compression in idiopathic carpal tunnel syndrome. NSAIDs are considered less effective than more targeted therapies.
questions.hint: This patient's characteristic symptoms, positive provocative maneuvers, and nerve conduction study findings are suggestive of moderate carpal tunnel syndrome.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman comes to an urgent care clinic because of a 2-month history of numbness and tingling in her right hand. The symptoms primarily affect her thumb, index, and middle fingers and are most pronounced at night, often waking her from sleep. She works as an administrative assistant and notes that prolonged typing exacerbates her symptoms. Shaking her hand provides temporary relief. On physical examination, there is a positive Phalen maneuver and Tinel sign over the right wrist. Sensation to light touch is mildly diminished over the first three digits. There is no thenar atrophy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapeutic intervention?

choices.text: Surgical decompression via carpal tunnel release
Nocturnal wrist splinting in a neutral position
Initiation of gabapentin for neuropathic pain
A short course of oral prednisone

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical carpal tunnel release is the definitive treatment for this condition. However, it is reserved for patients with severe symptoms, such as motor weakness or thenar atrophy, or for those for whom an adequate trial of conservative management has been unsuccessful. Since this patient has no evidence of muscle atrophy, proceeding directly to surgery as an initial intervention is not appropriate.

B) CORRECT:

The absence of thenar atrophy suggests mild-to-moderate disease, which is managed conservatively, e.g., with nocturnal wrist splinting being a cornerstone. Splinting the wrist in a neutral position prevents flexion or extension during sleep, which minimizes pressure within the carpal tunnel. This reduces compression on the median nerve, alleviating the characteristic nocturnal paresthesias and allowing the nerve to recover.

Alternatively, depending on patient preference, a glucocorticoid injection can be considered as an alternative first-line treatment to immobilization. It can provide significant symptom relief by reducing inflammation of the flexor tendon sheaths within the carpal tunnel.

C) INCORRECT:

Gabapentin is a medication used to treat neuropathic pain and could potentially mask the sensory symptoms of carpal tunnel syndrome. However, it does not address the underlying pathophysiology of median nerve compression. The primary goal of initial therapy is to relieve the mechanical compression, not just to treat the resulting symptoms. Therefore, it is not an appropriate initial intervention.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids can reduce inflammation and may provide temporary relief for carpal tunnel syndrome. However, their use is associated with systemic side effects, and they are generally considered less effective and provide less durable relief than local corticosteroid injections. They are not recommended as a first-line therapy.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of numbness and tingling that primarily affects the thumb, index, and middle fingers in the context of her occupation as an administrative assistant is consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome.
